title: 10 growth tactics that never work | Elena Verna (Amplitude, Miro, Dropbox, SurveyMonkey)
key_insights: Don't hire a head of growth until you have solid product-market fit and significant data volume - founders should lead growth initially
If your business growth is declining, hiring a growth team won't fix the underlying product or market issues
Homepage redesigns and rebrands typically hurt performance initially and require 3-6 months of optimization to recover
Focus 20-25% of growth team time annually on building owned/earned channels rather than relying entirely on paid acquisition
Testing everything creates paralysis - use pre/post analysis for low-traffic areas and reserve A/B tests for high-impact, high-volume initiatives
Your growth problems aren't unique - talk to people who've solved similar issues rather than starting from scratch
Diversify growth models every 18 months and expect to need new major growth engines every 5 years
Career optionality should be the north star rather than chasing specific titles or roles
topics_discussed: When to hire your first head of growth
Why growth teams can't fix declining businesses
Problems with homepage redesigns and rebrands
Copying competition vs. using for inspiration
Building earned vs. paid acquisition channels
Color optimization and friction removal myths
Third-party auth and email marketing misconceptions
Alternative career paths beyond full-time employment
memorable_quotes: To figure out your product market fit and how to distribute it, it's not something that you can outsource to somebody.
Never ever once have I seen a rebrand or redesign, especially of a marketing site, produce good performance results.
Your problem is not unique. I am 99% sure of that. Your problem has been felt by somebody somewhere in probably many, many places.
summary: Elena Verna shares 10 common growth tactics that consistently fail, from hiring growth teams too early to obsessing over homepage redesigns. She emphasizes building owned acquisition channels, avoiding over-experimentation, and viewing career development through the lens of optionality rather than titles.
